0,1 PER|2,3 GPE

The recent Iraq election was boycott by the Sunnis which constitute about 20 % of the population .
2,3 GPE|8,9 PER|16,17 GPE
2,3 GPE|8,9 PER|16,17 GPE

For example , in a city of 200,000 only 1400 had casted their votes .
5,6 GPE
5,6 GPE

6,7 PER|8,9 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 LOC
6,7 PER|8,9 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 LOC

1,2 GPE|7,8 FAC|1,8 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
1,2 GPE|7,8 FAC|1,8 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

If so , should that affect the legitimacy of the election ? ------------------



Sunnis say Iraq poll illegitimate A leading group of Iraqi Sunni clerics have said the country 's landmark election lacks legitimacy as so many Sunnis did not take part in the vote . The clerics had encouraged Sunnis to boycott the elections because of the presence of US and foreign troops .

Enron & amp ; India



Patrick Powers
0,2 PER
0,2 PER

4 Nov 2004 20:48:36 -0800



Enron & amp ; India
0,1 ORG|4,5 GPE
0,1 ORG|4,5 GPE

In India , Bechtel along with General Electric are the new owners of the notorious and currently defunct Enron power project .
1,2 GPE|3,4 ORG|6,8 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 ORG
1,2 GPE|3,4 ORG|6,8 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 ORG

The Enron contract , which legally binds the Government of the State of Maharashtra to pay Enron a sum of 30 billion dollars , was the largest contract ever signed in India .
1,2 ORG|8,9 GPE|11,12 GPE|13,14 GPE|16,17 ORG|31,32 GPE
1,2 ORG|8,9 GPE|11,12 GPE|13,14 GPE|16,17 ORG|31,32 GPE

Enron was not shy to boast about the millions of dollars it had spent to " educate " Indian politicians and bureaucrats .
0,1 ORG|18,19 GPE|19,20 PER|21,22 PER|18,20 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity|18,22 ORG-AFF.Employment
0,1 ORG|18,19 GPE|19,20 PER|21,22 PER|18,20 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity|18,22 ORG-AFF.Employment

The Enron contract in Maharashtra , which was India 's first ' fast - track ' private power project , has come to be known as the most massive fraud in the country 's history .
1,2 ORG|4,5 GPE|8,9 GPE|32,33 GPE
1,2 ORG|4,5 GPE|8,9 GPE|32,33 GPE

( Enron was another of the Republican Party 's major campaign contributors ) .
1,2 ORG|6,8 ORG|11,12 ORG
1,2 ORG|6,8 ORG|11,12 ORG

The electricity that Enron produced was so exorbitant that the government decided it was cheaper not to buy electricity and pay Enron the mandatory fixed charges specified in the contract .
3,4 ORG|10,11 GPE|21,22 ORG
3,4 ORG|10,11 GPE|21,22 ORG

This means that the government of one of the poorest countries in the world was paying Enron 220 million US dollars a year not to produce electricity !
4,5 GPE|10,11 GPE|13,14 LOC|16,17 ORG|19,20 GPE|10,14 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
4,5 GPE|10,11 GPE|13,14 LOC|16,17 ORG|19,20 GPE|10,14 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

Now that Enron has ceased to exist , Bechtel and GE are suing the Indian Government for 5.6 billion US dollars .
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG|10,11 ORG|14,15 GPE|15,16 GPE|19,20 GPE
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG|10,11 ORG|14,15 GPE|15,16 GPE|19,20 GPE

This is not even a minute fraction of the sum of money that they ( or Enron ) actually invested in the project .
16,17 ORG
16,17 ORG

Once more , it 's a projection of profit they would have made had the project materialized .



zztop8970

" Maharashtra officials say the cost of power supplied by Enron is nearly double the tariff charged by Indian power producers , and used it as an excuse to stop paying state debts to the plant . "

" Enron had signed a power purchase agreement with power utility MSEB eight years ago , under which a $ 3bn 2,182 Megawatt power plant was to be commissioned .

1,2 ORG|10,11 ORG|11,12 ORG|24,25 FAC

Though Enron officials refuse to talk about the price they would be willing to sell their stake at , analysts say the US company is demanding about one billion dollars for its investments in India .

Fri , 28 Jan 2005 17:09:12 + 0000 ( UTC )



Re : U.S. provoked Japan ?
2,3 GPE|4,5 GPE
2,3 GPE|4,5 GPE

I 've read quite a few more rational works describing how the US was doing its best to avoid , or at the very least postpone , a war against Japan , mainly because FDR was trying to provoke Hitler to war and did n't need a distraction on another distant front .
12,13 GPE|30,31 GPE|34,35 PER|39,40 PER
12,13 GPE|30,31 GPE|34,35 PER|39,40 PER

work ?



( stuff deleted )



The thesis has been expounded by several conspiracy theorists , mainly the ones who expounded that FDR knew Pearl Harbor was about to be attacked , and let it happen .
8,9 PER|16,17 PER|18,20 FAC
8,9 PER|16,17 PER|18,20 FAC

One of their " proofs " was that the US carriers were out of port during the attack , and " everybody knew " carriers were the capital ship of the future .
9,10 GPE|10,11 VEH|24,25 VEH|28,29 VEH|9,11 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer
9,10 GPE|10,11 VEH|24,25 VEH|28,29 VEH|9,11 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer

However , the two carriers operating out of Pearl at the moment were sent West with light escort , on possibly intersecting routes with the IJN Kido Butai , which had far more carriers and a far heavier escort . Even stranger , the USS Enterprise was scheduled to be at Pearl by Dec 6th , but got delayed by a storm .
4,5 VEH|8,9 FAC|17,18 VEH|25,26 ORG|26,28 VEH|33,34 VEH|38,39 VEH|44,46 VEH|51,52 FAC|25,27 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer|25,28 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer
4,5 VEH|8,9 FAC|17,18 VEH|25,26 ORG|26,28 VEH|33,34 VEH|38,39 VEH|44,46 VEH|51,52 FAC|25,28 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer

Consequently , for the PH conspiracy theorists to believe that FDR kept the carriers out of harm 's way , we not only have to grant FDR the full knowledge of Kido Butai 's route of approach would not result in either USN carrier fleet getting caught in a hopeless battle , but that FDR could psychically manipulate the weather to prevent Halsey from sailing into Pearl and thus be ambushed .
6,7 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 VEH|26,27 PER|31,33 VEH|42,43 ORG|43,44 VEH|44,45 VEH|54,55 PER|62,63 PER|66,67 FAC|42,45 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer|43,45 PART-WHOLE.Artifact
6,7 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 VEH|26,27 PER|31,33 VEH|42,43 ORG|43,44 VEH|44,45 VEH|54,55 PER|62,63 PER|66,67 FAC|42,45 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer|43,45 PART-WHOLE.Artifact

To make a very long story short , it is foolish to assume that the US wanted to go to war against Japan prior to 1941 , considering the weight of evidence arguing against a US desire for war , and the overwhelming lack of evidence ( not to mention rational thought ) arguing for a US desire for war . --
15,16 GPE|22,23 GPE|35,36 GPE|56,57 GPE

mtfes ... @netMAPSONscape.net

0,3 PER

Fri , 28 Jan 2005 17:08:52 + 0000 ( UTC )



Re : U.S. provoked Japan ?
2,3 GPE|4,5 GPE
2,3 GPE|4,5 GPE

Here 's something I wrote as part of a larger article , some while ago :



Was n't Japan just defending herself when she attacked the US ?
2,3 GPE|10,11 GPE
2,3 GPE|10,11 GPE

This line of reasoning seems to derive from arguments that Japan was being " driven into a corner " by sanctions , and had no choice but to attack the US .
10,11 GPE|30,31 GPE
10,11 GPE|30,31 GPE

Meiji Japan was driven to emulate what it thought the West was doing in every facet of society .
0,2 GPE|10,11 GPE
0,2 GPE|10,11 GPE

They had observed , for example , that the West was able to carve up China into " Spheres of Influence " , and was able to do from great distances , while they , the Japanese , had had limited success in their previous attempts to dominate the Korean peninsula , much less China .
9,10 GPE|15,16 GPE|36,37 GPE|49,51 GPE|54,55 GPE
9,10 GPE|15,16 GPE|36,37 GPE|49,51 GPE|54,55 GPE

As part of the catch - up effort , she whole - heartedly entered into the Imperialist game in Asia , being treated as an equal ( relative to her power ) by the other powers .
19,20 GPE|25,26 GPE|35,36 GPE
19,20 GPE|25,26 GPE|35,36 GPE

However , after World War I , Japan failed to recognize a fundamental shift in the attitudes of her former Imperial partners ; they began a long , slow process of disengaging themselves from their former Imperial areas , from their colonies , in addition to outright stopping all expansions .
7,8 GPE|21,22 GPE|37,38 LOC|41,42 LOC
7,8 GPE|21,22 GPE|37,38 LOC|41,42 LOC

Japan chose to read this as a sign that the West had lost its power and resolve , and that Japan was the rightful heir to Imperial mantle in Asia .
0,1 GPE|10,11 GPE|20,21 GPE|24,25 GPE|29,30 GPE
0,1 GPE|10,11 GPE|20,21 GPE|24,25 GPE|29,30 GPE

With the deaths of many of the idealistic leaders who had led Japan 's rise to international prominence , and the refusal of the US to intervene in Asian affairs , in addition to the Bolshevik revolution and the stripping of possessions from Germany , Britain found herself alone in dealing with an increasingly aggressive Japan in the area .
8,9 PER|12,13 GPE|24,25 GPE|28,29 GPE|35,36 PER|41,42 LOC|43,44 GPE|45,46 GPE|55,56 GPE|58,59 LOC|55,59 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
8,9 PER|12,13 GPE|24,25 GPE|28,29 GPE|35,36 PER|41,42 LOC|43,44 GPE|45,46 GPE|55,56 GPE|58,59 LOC|55,59 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

Having a keen grasp of the obvious , she began a policy of acceding to Japanese hegemony in the area .
15,16 GPE|19,20 LOC
15,16 GPE|19,20 LOC

Japan continued a policy of acquiring territory for some grand , illusive scheme of a " Greater Asia " , subordinate and grateful to Japan .
0,1 GPE|6,7 LOC|16,18 LOC|24,25 GPE|0,7 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
0,1 GPE|6,7 LOC|16,18 LOC|24,25 GPE|0,7 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

The reality of this was that only a single possession , Manchuria , was profitable to the Japanese , and the rest of the Empire turned out to be a drain .
9,10 LOC|11,12 LOC|17,18 GPE|24,25 GPE|9,18 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
9,10 LOC|11,12 LOC|17,18 GPE|24,25 GPE|9,18 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

This drain was greatly accelerated by Japan 's invasion of China proper in 1936 .
6,7 GPE|10,11 GPE
6,7 GPE|10,11 GPE

It was a war that Japan assumed would be ended in " 3 to 6 months " ; at the time of Pearl Harbor , it had been going on for 5 years , at the cost of over half a million Japanese lives .
5,6 GPE|22,24 FAC|42,43 GPE|43,44 PER|42,44 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity
5,6 GPE|22,24 FAC|42,43 GPE|43,44 PER|42,44 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity

The war put a tremendous strain on Japan ( and was in fact opposed by more radically NATIONALISTIC elements , as taking away from the development of Japan 's other possessions , particularly in the areas of scrap metal and fuel . ) Domestic consumption fell , consumer goods became scarce , and the use of materiale for war purposes ate into Japan 's domestic industry .
7,8 GPE|18,19 PER|27,28 GPE|30,31 LOC|62,63 GPE|27,31 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
7,8 GPE|18,19 PER|27,28 GPE|30,31 LOC|62,63 GPE|27,31 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

This cut further into her foreign reserves , exacerbating the economic impact of the war .



The war effort took on a life of its own , however , and common sense was subordinated to it .



Japan expanded into areas of China and Indochina which had no strategic value to her , but put her in a position to threaten British and Dutch possessions in the area ; possessions that both those Allied nations needed in order to continue their fight against Hitler .
0,1 GPE|3,4 LOC|5,6 GPE|7,8 GPE|24,25 GPE|26,27 GPE|27,28 LOC|30,31 LOC|32,33 LOC|36,37 GPE|37,38 GPE|46,47 PER|3,6 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|3,8 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|24,28 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|26,28 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|27,31 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
0,1 GPE|3,4 LOC|5,6 GPE|7,8 GPE|24,25 GPE|26,27 GPE|27,28 LOC|30,31 LOC|32,33 LOC|36,37 GPE|37,38 GPE|46,47 PER|3,6 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|3,8 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|24,28 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|26,28 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|27,31 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

At this point , the US stopped ignoring the Japanese threat , and imposed a series of escalating sanctions on Japan , cutting off her scrap metal , limitting and then cutting off her oil ( Japan imported most of both from the US . ) While Japanese officials realized that they had enough of each resource for Japan to do well IF THE WAR IN CHINA STOPPED , they were powerless over the military they were supposed to control .
5,6 GPE|9,10 GPE|20,21 GPE|36,37 GPE|43,44 GPE|47,48 GPE|48,49 PER|58,59 GPE|66,67 GPE|74,75 ORG|47,49 ORG-AFF.Employment
5,6 GPE|9,10 GPE|20,21 GPE|36,37 GPE|43,44 GPE|47,48 GPE|48,49 PER|58,59 GPE|66,67 GPE|74,75 ORG|47,49 ORG-AFF.Employment

An abortive attack on Soviet positions in Mongolia had placed Japan 's focus firmly south , towards the possessions of the US ' future allies .
4,5 GPE|7,8 GPE|10,11 GPE|18,19 LOC|21,22 GPE|24,25 GPE|18,25 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
4,5 GPE|7,8 GPE|10,11 GPE|18,19 LOC|21,22 GPE|24,25 GPE|18,25 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

For no reason anyone could articulate , Japan felt she had to continue the war in China .
7,8 GPE|16,17 GPE
7,8 GPE|16,17 GPE

To continue the war in China , she had to have resources of oil and metal .
5,6 GPE
5,6 GPE

To have these resources , she must seize them , if others refused to sell them .
11,12 GPE
11,12 GPE

In order to seize them , she felt she had to attack and destroy the naval power of the US .
19,20 GPE
19,20 GPE

Thus , for a " 3 to 6 month " operation in China in 1937 , Japan would embark on a war that would strip her of all the possessions and industries she had acquired in 70 years .

The 1860 Presidential Election



Machiavegli
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

29 Jan 2005 22:04:38 GMT



The 1860 Presidential Election



In 1860 there was a four - way race between the Republican Party with Abraham Lincold , the Democratic Party with Stephen Douglas , the Southern Democratic Party with John Breckenridge , and the Constitutional Union Party with John Bell .
11,13 ORG|14,16 PER|18,20 ORG|21,23 PER|25,28 ORG|29,31 PER|34,37 ORG|38,40 PER|11,15 ORG-AFF.Membership|12,15 ORG-AFF.Membership|11,16 ORG-AFF.Membership|12,16 ORG-AFF.Membership|18,22 ORG-AFF.Membership|19,22 ORG-AFF.Membership|18,23 ORG-AFF.Membership|19,23 ORG-AFF.Membership|25,30 ORG-AFF.Membership|26,30 ORG-AFF.Membership|27,30 ORG-AFF.Membership|25,31 ORG-AFF.Membership|26,31 ORG-AFF.Membership|27,31 ORG-AFF.Membership|34,39 ORG-AFF.Membership|35,39 ORG-AFF.Membership|36,39 ORG-AFF.Membership|34,40 ORG-AFF.Membership|35,40 ORG-AFF.Membership|36,40 ORG-AFF.Membership
11,13 ORG|14,16 PER|18,20 ORG|21,23 PER|25,28 ORG|29,31 PER|34,37 ORG|38,40 PER|11,16 ORG-AFF.Membership|18,23 ORG-AFF.Membership|25,31 ORG-AFF.Membership|34,40 ORG-AFF.Membership

Lincoln won a plurality with about 40 % of the vote . WI it was only a two - way race between Lincoln and Douglas ?
0,1 PER|22,23 PER|24,25 PER
0,1 PER|22,23 PER|24,25 PER

I believe Douglas would have won . This would have delayed secession and the Civil War .
2,3 PER
2,3 PER

Re : The 1860 Presidential Election



machiave...@aol.com ( Machiavegli ) wrote in
2,3 PER
2,3 PER

" One feature of the result must not be omitted .



Many careless observers felt at the time that the success of Lincoln was due entirely to the fact of there having been three opposing candidates in the field ; or , in other words , to the dissensions in the Democratic party , which divided its vote between Breckinridge and Douglas .
2,3 PER|11,12 PER|24,25 PER|40,42 ORG|48,49 PER|50,51 PER
2,3 PER|11,12 PER|24,25 PER|40,42 ORG|48,49 PER|50,51 PER

What merely moral strength the Democratic party would have gained had it remained united , it is impossible to estimate .
5,7 ORG
5,7 ORG

Such a supposition can only be based on the absence of the extreme Southern doctrines concerning slavery .
13,14 LOC
13,14 LOC

Given the presence of those doctrines in the canvass , no hypothesis can furnish a result different from that which occurred .



In the contest upon the questions as they existed , the victory of Lincoln was certain .
13,14 PER
13,14 PER

If all the votes given to all the opposing candidates had been concentrated and cast for a ' fusion ticket , ' as was wholly or partly done in five States , the result would have been changed nowhere except in New Jersey , California , and Oregon ; Lincoln would still have received but 11 fewer , or 169 electoral votes -- majority of 35 in the entire electoral college . " Abraham Lincoln , A History , Volume 2 by John George Nicolay and John Hay
9,10 PER|30,31 GPE|41,43 GPE|44,45 GPE|47,48 GPE|49,50 PER|70,71 ORG|82,85 PER|86,88 PER
9,10 PER|30,31 GPE|41,43 GPE|44,45 GPE|47,48 GPE|49,50 PER|70,71 ORG|82,85 PER|86,88 PER

See for a confirmation of the electoral arithmetic : the states where Lincoln got an abolute majority of the popular vote ( i.e. , all the free states except Oregon , California , and New Jersey ) were sufficient to bring him a majority in the Electoral College .
10,11 GPE|12,13 PER|27,28 GPE|29,30 GPE|31,32 GPE|34,36 GPE|47,48 ORG
10,11 GPE|12,13 PER|27,28 GPE|29,30 GPE|31,32 GPE|34,36 GPE|47,48 ORG

The reason that Lincoln could get an electoral majority with only forty percent of the popular vote was not that his opposition was divided but that he had far fewer " wasted " votes than his opponents -- in ten southern states he got no popular votes at all .
3,4 PER|36,37 PER|41,42 GPE
3,4 PER|36,37 PER|41,42 GPE

It can of course be argued that the candidate of a united anti - Lincoln opposition might have done better than all the OTL anti - Lincoln candidates combined , because the mere fact of the divided nature of Lincoln 's opposition might have discouraged anti - Lincoln men and led to fewer of them voting than would otherwise be the case .
8,9 PER|14,15 PER|26,27 PER|27,28 PER|39,40 PER|41,42 PER|47,48 PER|48,49 PER
8,9 PER|14,15 PER|26,27 PER|27,28 PER|39,40 PER|41,42 PER|47,48 PER|48,49 PER

But given that turnout was quite high in 1860 , I doubt this .



One thing seems reasonably clear to me : if there was to be a united anti- Lincoln opposition , Douglas could not lead it .
16,17 PER|19,20 PER
16,17 PER|19,20 PER

He was hated too much in the South for his opposition to the admission of Kansas as a state under the pro - slavery Lecompton Constitution and for his interpretation of Dred Scott as still allowing territories to exclude slavery through unfriendly local legislation .
7,8 LOC|15,16 GPE|18,19 GPE|36,37 LOC
7,8 LOC|15,16 GPE|18,19 GPE|36,37 LOC

( See



for Douglas 's defense of his position . ) He and Breckinridge and Bell would have to withdraw in favor of a compromise candidate -- former governor Horatio Seymour of New York was one proposal .
1,2 PER|11,12 PER|13,14 PER|23,24 PER|26,27 PER|27,29 PER|30,32 GPE|27,31 ORG-AFF.Employment|27,32 ORG-AFF.Employment|28,31 ORG-AFF.Employment|28,32 ORG-AFF.Employment
1,2 PER|11,12 PER|13,14 PER|23,24 PER|26,27 PER|27,29 PER|30,32 GPE|27,32 ORG-AFF.Employment

But I doubt that Seymour would have been able to do better than all the combined OTL anti - Lincoln candidates in such close states as Illinois and Indiana And his own state of New York was not really close enough for me to believe he could have taken that state from the Lincoln column . -- David Tenner dten...@ameritech.net

0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2004 - 11 - 01T11:44:00 Again I apologize for the lack of updates over the past few days and will use this space to recap a weekend that was both good and bad .



The Good :



On Friday a small group of friends and I attended a most - righteous Sister Hazel concert at Floyd 's Music Store for the third straight , and for the third straight year I was blown away by one of my favorite live bands .
4,5 PER|6,7 PER|14,16 ORG|18,22 FAC|43,44 ORG
4,5 PER|6,7 PER|14,16 ORG|18,22 FAC|43,44 ORG

Sister Hazel has a way of becoming intimate with the fans by brining them into the show .
0,2 ORG|10,11 PER
0,2 ORG|10,11 PER

It 's something you can always expect from these guys , unlike so many other performers , and is why I never miss a show when they 're in town .
9,10 ORG|15,16 PER|29,30 GPE
9,10 ORG|15,16 PER|29,30 GPE

On Saturday we hosted what was for the most part a largely successful Halloween party -- save for the fake blood stains on the carpet and bathroom walls , a couple beer spills , unnecessary fights and the expected trashing of the kitchen and living room areas .
26,27 FAC|42,43 FAC|44,46 FAC|46,47 FAC
26,27 FAC|42,43 FAC|44,46 FAC|46,47 FAC

Naturally , I dressed up as Hugh Hefner and took the role of making sure everyone was having a good time .
6,8 PER
6,8 PER

I have yet to hear any complaints from any of the guests .
11,12 PER
11,12 PER

The Bad :



On Saturday the Seminoles were bested by unranked Maryland ; effectively ending our chances at a national title this year .
3,4 ORG|8,9 ORG
3,4 ORG|8,9 ORG

In addition , the quarterback controversy has once again debouched as Chris Rix almost took us to victory with his deep threat .
4,5 PER|11,13 PER
4,5 PER|11,13 PER

Alas , too little too late was the case thanks to the inept Wyatt Sexton who has been our starter since replacing Rix earlier in the season .
13,15 PER|19,20 PER|22,23 PER
13,15 PER|19,20 PER|22,23 PER

Fortunately the agony of defeat was blanketed somewhat by our Halloween party and I wo n't have to worry about Seminole Football until next Saturday .
20,21 ORG
20,21 ORG

On Sunday we saw " Saw " ( review coming ) and as expected I was less than satisfied .



It was neither better nor worse than last week 's " The Grudge " but the trailers beforehand dictate that the end of this year and the beginning of 2005 will bring us a large quantity of horror movies .



If I enjoy one out of five considering the genre I can say it 's worth it .

2004 - 11 - 01T18:06:00 I wish I could have been at a Pub , or wherever these people convene , to see the reactions from all the Britons who read the Telegraph this morning ( emphasis added ) : Britain 's gun laws are aimed at the wrong target , curbing and criminalising legal ownership while failing to tackle huge rises in shooting offences over the past few years , according to an international firearms legislation expert .

Prof Gary Mauser said that Britain was making the same mistake as Canada and Australia in focusing on legal owners - a section of the law - abiding community where gun crimes , such as the Dunblane massacre , were aberrations .

Life - Saving Disease



Scott
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2004 - 12 - 03T19:59:00 Here 's an incredible story about an unsung hero until now .
13,14 PER
13,14 PER

From BBC News : A retired Italian doctor has revealed for the first time how he invented a fictitious disease which fooled the Nazis during World War II .
1,3 ORG|6,7 GPE|7,8 PER|23,24 PER|6,8 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity
1,3 ORG|6,7 GPE|7,8 PER|23,24 PER|6,8 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity

The trick of prescribing Jews with a mysterious illness terrified the Nazis and saved 45 Roman Jews .
4,5 PER|11,12 PER|15,16 GPE|16,17 PER|15,17 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity
4,5 PER|11,12 PER|15,16 GPE|16,17 PER|15,17 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity

Dr Vittorio Sacerdoti has told his remarkable tale on the 60th anniversary of liberation of Rome .
1,3 PER|15,16 GPE
1,3 PER|15,16 GPE

Just 28 years old at the time , he used courage and ingenuity to save 45 people from certain death .
16,17 PER
16,17 PER

As other Jews were being rounded up , Dr Sacerdoti admitted anyone who could reach the hospital as patients - and diagnosed them with a dangerous disease .
2,3 PER|9,10 PER|16,17 FAC|18,19 PER
2,3 PER|9,10 PER|16,17 FAC|18,19 PER

" We would write on their medical forms that the patient was suffering from K Syndrome , " he said .
10,11 PER
10,11 PER

" We called it K after the German commander Kesserling - the Nazis thought it was cancer or tuberculosis , and they fled like rabbits . "
7,8 GPE|8,9 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 PER|7,9 ORG-AFF.Employment
7,8 GPE|8,9 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 PER|7,9 ORG-AFF.Employment

K Syndrome saved his cousin , Luciana Sacerdoti , who was just 10 years old .
4,5 PER|6,8 PER
4,5 PER|6,8 PER

" The day the Nazis came to the hospital , someone came to our room and said : ' You have to cough , you have to cough a lot because they are afraid of the coughing , they do n't want to catch an awful disease and they wo n't enter ' . "

2005 - 01 - 27T10:17:00 The Augusta Free Press ( motto : " Our only agenda is the truth " ) has a Chris Graham story on a Del. Chap Peterson , D - Fairfax , bill that would require payback by companies lured to Virginia by incentives if they do not stay for five years .
6,9 ORG|23,25 PER|28,29 PER|29,31 PER|32,33 ORG|34,35 GPE|45,46 GPE

Leslie Byrne , as approving of the measure because it 's " something that I 've been talking about for some time now . "

? ? ? ?



-??-??T09:01:00 Hand in hand with any consideration of the redistricting process , we shoul give some thought to the structural relationship between the state House and Senate .
23,24 GPE|24,25 ORG|26,27 ORG|23,25 ORG-AFF.Employment|23,27 ORG-AFF.Employment
23,24 GPE|24,25 ORG|26,27 ORG|23,25 ORG-AFF.Employment|23,27 ORG-AFF.Employment

Currently , each House member represents approximately 75,000 Virginians , while each Senator represents appoximately 187,500 . Often as not , there is no rational commonality between the two .
3,4 ORG|4,5 PER|8,9 PER|12,13 PER|3,5 ORG-AFF.Membership
3,4 ORG|4,5 PER|8,9 PER|12,13 PER|3,5 ORG-AFF.Membership

1,2 PER|3,4 PER|4,5 PER|14,15 ORG|15,16 LOC
1,2 PER|3,4 PER|4,5 PER|14,15 ORG|15,16 LOC

I believe this accounts , in large part , for the dysfunction that characterizes our state government now .
15,16 GPE|16,17 GPE
15,16 GPE|16,17 GPE

Former Governor Gerald Baliles , in this same vein , has advocated a realignment of the two houses in a way that serves commonalities .
1,2 PER|2,4 PER|17,18 PER
1,2 PER|2,4 PER|17,18 PER

He has suggested that we either increase membership in the Senate to 50 , or decrease House membership to 80 , producing a scenario wherein 1 Senator would represent a block of people who are represented by exactly 2 Delegates .
7,8 PER|10,11 ORG|16,17 ORG|17,18 PER|26,27 PER|30,31 PER|39,40 PER|7,11 ORG-AFF.Membership|16,18 ORG-AFF.Membership
7,8 PER|10,11 ORG|16,17 ORG|17,18 PER|26,27 PER|30,31 PER|39,40 PER|7,11 ORG-AFF.Membership|16,18 ORG-AFF.Membership

He thinks -- and I think he is right -- that this arrangement would foster a closer working relationship between the Senate and the House .
21,22 ORG|24,25 ORG
21,22 ORG|24,25 ORG

You certainly would n't have these dysfunctional groupings we now have , where 1 Senator often represents a population divided among half a dozen Delegates of two parties -- three , if you count independents .

Where is Investigative Journalism ?



Will Vehrs
0,2 PER
0,2 PER

2005 - 02 - 27T12:38:00 Governor Mark Warner has turned state government upside - down in an effort to do more business with small , women , and minority owned ( SWAM ) firms and the thanks he gets are headlines like this one in the Daily Press : Warner 's plan to raise contracting diversity falls short .
5,6 PER|6,8 PER|10,11 GPE|11,12 GPE|25,26 PER|28,29 PER|33,34 ORG|49,50 PER|25,34 ORG-AFF.Ownership|28,34 ORG-AFF.Ownership
5,6 PER|6,8 PER|10,11 GPE|11,12 GPE|25,26 PER|28,29 PER|33,34 ORG|49,50 PER|25,34 ORG-AFF.Ownership|28,34 ORG-AFF.Ownership

The article is full of innuendo that procurement officals are ignoring the Governor 's wishes and just waiting for him to leave office , that " special deals " are cut with non - SWAM vendors , and that somehow the electronic procurement system is " stacked " against SWAM firms .
8,9 PER|12,13 PER|34,35 ORG|35,36 ORG|49,50 ORG|50,51 ORG
8,9 PER|12,13 PER|34,35 ORG|35,36 ORG|49,50 ORG|50,51 ORG

If true , these are serious charges , worthy of high - level investigation .



What 's missing from the article , though , is any attempt at investigative journalism to give even one factual example supporting the innuendo .



What 's also missing is a fair - minded review of whether the sagging numbers reported for SWAM procurement are valid .
17,18 ORG
17,18 ORG

Someday a journalist is going to take the time to watch a sample number of SWAM firms submit bids on openly posted contracts , then use procurement tools that are in place to determine if any SWAM firms were unfairly denied contracts they deserved .
2,3 PER|15,16 ORG|16,17 ORG|36,37 ORG|37,38 ORG
2,3 PER|15,16 ORG|16,17 ORG|36,37 ORG|37,38 ORG

Until then , this carping appears to be sour grapes .



Governor Warner has done plenty to open up the system to SWAM firms and give them a presumptive advantage , even inviting a backlash by non - SWAM firms .
0,1 PER|1,2 PER|11,12 ORG|12,13 ORG|27,28 ORG|28,29 ORG

I found the following report that was presented to Congress recently about the shoulder launched missle threat to airliners , which this might very well be a precursor to : Recent events have focused attention on the threat that terrorists with shoulder fired surface - to - air missiles ( SAMs ) , referred to as Man - Portable Air Defense Systems ( MANPADS ) , pose to commercial airliners .
9,10 ORG|15,16 WEA|18,19 VEH|39,40 PER|48,49 WEA|50,51 WEA|56,62 WEA|63,64 WEA|69,70 VEH|39,49 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer
9,10 ORG|15,16 WEA|18,19 VEH|39,40 PER|48,49 WEA|50,51 WEA|56,62 WEA|63,64 WEA|69,70 VEH|39,49 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer

Most believe that no single solution exists to effectively mitigate this threat .



Instead , a menu of options may be considered , including installing infrared ( IR ) countermeasures on aircraft ; modifying flight operations and air traffic control procedures ; improving airport and regional security ; and strengthening missile non - proliferation efforts .
18,19 VEH|30,31 FAC|37,38 WEA
18,19 VEH|30,31 FAC|37,38 WEA

Equipping aircraft with missile countermeasure systems can protect the aircraft even when operating in areas where ground - based security measures are unavailable or infeasible to implement .
1,2 VEH|3,4 WEA|9,10 VEH|14,15 LOC
1,2 VEH|3,4 WEA|9,10 VEH|14,15 LOC

However , this option has a relatively high cost , between $ 1 million and $ 3 million per aircraft , and the time needed for implementation does not allow for immediate response to the existing terrorist threat .
19,20 VEH|36,37 PER
19,20 VEH|36,37 PER

Procedural improvements such as specific flight crew training , altering air traffic procedures to minimize exposure to the threat , and improved security near airports may be less costly than countermeasures and could more immediately help deter domestic terrorist attacks .
6,7 PER|24,25 FAC|37,38 GPE|38,39 PER
6,7 PER|24,25 FAC|37,38 GPE|38,39 PER

However , these techniques by themselves can not completely mitigate the risk of domestic attacks and would not protect U.S. airliners flying to and from foreign airports .
13,14 GPE|19,20 GPE|20,21 VEH|26,27 FAC
13,14 GPE|19,20 GPE|20,21 VEH|26,27 FAC

Legislation introduced in the 108th Congress ( H.R. 580 , S. 311 ) calls for the installation of missile defense systems in all turbojet aircraft used in scheduled air carrier service .
5,6 ORG|18,19 WEA|24,25 VEH
5,6 ORG|18,19 WEA|24,25 VEH

While this legislation is still under consideration , Homeland Security appropriations designated $ 60 million in FY2004 and $ 61 million in FY2005 to fund a program to develop and test prototype missile countermeasure systems for commercial aircraft based on existing military technology .
8,10 ORG|32,33 WEA|37,38 VEH|41,42 ORG
8,10 ORG|32,33 WEA|37,38 VEH|41,42 ORG

It is anticipated that at the conclusion of this program , in January 2006 , the Department of Homeland Security will be able to provide a detailed analysis of the suitability of such systems for use to protect commercial passenger aircraft .

Why you ask ?



But there is arguably more to this sea change than just a grumpy acceptance of the status quo .



From a European perspective , three things are making it easier to warm to the Bush White House .
2,3 GPE|15,16 PER|16,18 ORG|15,17 ORG-AFF.Membership|15,18 ORG-AFF.Membership

2,3 PER|6,7 GPE|8,9 GPE|18,20 PER|23,24 LOC|28,29 GPE|32,33 GPE|40,42 PER|46,47 GPE|47,48 PER|46,48 ORG-AFF.Employment

A second reason is Europe 's growing worries about Islamic terrorism . The murder in November of Theo van Gogh , a provocative Dutch filmmaker , at the hands of an Islamic militant has been called Europe 's 9/11 . Though the two events are obviously not fully comparable , it is certainly true that American conservatives , such as Francis Fukuyama and Bernard Lewis , have found a wider audience recently for the idea that radical Islam is inimical to European traditions of tolerance .

2004 - 11 - 08T19:42:06 The interim government declared a state of emergency in Iraq excluding the Kurdish region for 60 days , according to the National Security Law introduced last August which states that emergency laws can be declared in the country for a period no more than 60 days provided a serious threat against Iraqi national security is recognised by the interim government .

Daylight Savings Time is retarded



Mark Backer
0,2 PER
0,2 PER

2004 - 11 - 03T13:00:00 I am 36 years old .



I 've been around a while .



I 'm not 87 or anything , but I 've seen some things in my life .



I have initially agreed and disagreed with different things over the years , only to have my mind changed later .



However , I will never EVER change my mind about the idiocy we call Daylight Savings Time .



I Googled " Daylight Savings Time " and I got the following link :



http://webexhibits.org/daylightsaving/



I started reading ...



The site says things like " We 've learned to save energy and enjoy sunny summer evenings by switching our clocks an hour forward in the summer " and there 's no S at the end of Savings .



It should be Daylight Saving Time .



My apologies to the assclowns that invented this idiocy and the goobers that perpetuate it in such a ridiculous fashion .
4,5 PER|11,12 PER
4,5 PER|11,12 PER

I will concede that " springing forward " and " falling back " are good ways to remember to change the batteries in your smoke detectors . However , New Years and the Fourth of July would do the same thing .



I kept reading the website of propoganda and found that the first person to come up with the idea was Benjamin Franklin who did it on behalf of some friends that owned oil companies ( oil was used in lamps ) .
12,13 PER|20,22 PER|29,30 PER|33,34 ORG
12,13 PER|20,22 PER|29,30 PER|33,34 ORG

I assume that , because the idea was dumb and inconvenient , lots of people ignored it . " By 1966 , some 100 million Americans were observing DST based on their own local laws and customs .
14,15 PER|25,26 PER
14,15 PER|25,26 PER

Congress decided to step in to end the confusion and establish one pattern across the country . The Uniform Time Act of 1966 ( 15 U.S. Code Section 260a ) which was signed into Public Law 89 - 387 on 12 April 1966 , by President Lyndon Johnson , created Daylight Saving Tim to begin on the last Sunday of April and to end on the last Sunday of October .
0,1 ORG|15,16 GPE|25,26 GPE|45,46 PER|46,48 PER
0,1 ORG|15,16 GPE|25,26 GPE|45,46 PER|46,48 PER

Any State that wanted to be exempt from DST could do so by passing a state law .
1,2 GPE|15,16 GPE
1,2 GPE|15,16 GPE

There 's a LOT more to this since then , and you can read a lot more it if you want to , but this is what I know :



Indiana 's eastern half does n't use it .
0,1 GPE|3,4 LOC|0,4 PART-WHOLE.Geographical
0,1 GPE|3,4 LOC|0,4 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

What 's THAT all about ?



Arizona does n't use it because one tribe of Indians stretches into three states .
0,1 GPE|7,8 PER|9,10 PER|13,14 GPE|7,14 PHYS.Located
0,1 GPE|7,8 PER|9,10 PER|13,14 GPE|7,14 PHYS.Located

But those other states DO use it .
3,4 GPE
3,4 GPE

Hawaii does n't use it at all .
0,1 GPE
0,1 GPE

Of course , they 're closer to Japan than to us , and since Japan does n't use it , Hawaii just plays along .
7,8 GPE|14,15 GPE|20,21 GPE
7,8 GPE|14,15 GPE|20,21 GPE

( Do you think the Hawaiian 's sit around , staring west , just becuase they still do n't trust the Japs ? )
5,7 GPE|21,22 GPE
5,7 GPE|21,22 GPE

Regardless of when I go to bed ( 11 pm or 10 pm or 9 pm ) , I get up at 5:30 and I am fucking exhausted .



How can that be ?



I slept the same number of hours as I did two weeks ago , yet I 'm tired ?



Also , I am so hungry I could eat my little tub of Carmex by 10:30am every day .



I used to eat lunch between 11:30 and noon , but now , eating is all I think about after 10 am .



Why is that good for me ?



I do n't care if America saves 1 % of its energy consumption costs during those times .
5,6 GPE
5,6 GPE

I am tired , hungry , and I leave for work and get home from work in the dark .
13,14 FAC
13,14 FAC

MARKETVIEW_20041211.1845



WEB TEXT



2004 - 12 - 11T18:45:00



Video Rentals : The Three Hypotheses



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2004 - 12 - 11T18:45:00 Scrappy underdog Netflix had its day earlier in the year , when it became one of the hottest stocks around ( sporting an eye - popping P / E in the high 900 's on the way up , and , thanks to a poor earnings report , over 1,000 on the way down ) .
6,7 ORG|7,8 ORG
6,7 ORG|7,8 ORG

There 's plenty of argument about the future of DVD and video rental , and Netflix represents a pure - play on one of the three dominant hypotheses :
15,16 ORG
15,16 ORG

I. That business is O - V - E - R -- Between pay - per - view , video - on - demand , pirated movies , high - bandwidth Internet broadcasts , and the increasing availability of other media , it takes some faith to see any future for movie rentals .
2,3 ORG
2,3 ORG

Those who do n't have the requisite faith will point to these factors as proof that the business is dying and the movie business in general will need a pretty significant overhaul before it can make profits .
17,18 ORG|23,24 ORG
17,18 ORG|23,24 ORG

Movie rentals are no longer a cheap alternative to other ways of viewing films ; they 're the stodgy , expensive way .



There are n't any pure - play buys on this theory , but someone who believes it might overweight their portfolio in cable companies -- if they purchased any media stocks at all .
23,24 ORG
23,24 ORG

Of course , there have been companies whose performance would perfectly mimic the validity of this idea , but Psuedo.com failed without producing a single show , and Broadcast.com was swallowed for $ 6 billion by Yahoo ! , to Yahoo ! 's great regret .
6,7 ORG|19,20 ORG|28,29 ORG|36,37 ORG|40,41 ORG
6,7 ORG|19,20 ORG|28,29 ORG|36,37 ORG|40,41 ORG

II .



Not so fast -- it 'll just go online ! -- Anyone who wants to counter that argument would probably start by taking us back to 1997 , when in terms of time used , text was the most popular kind of information online .



At the time , and for years after , people argued that the traditional bookstore would become obsolete .
9,10 PER|14,15 FAC
9,10 PER|14,15 FAC

After all , how could we stand for a rapaciously arborcidal medium like ' books ' or ' newspapers ' when we could transmit the same data as bits and bytes and save on transportation , too ?



As it turns out , of course , Amazon.com , BarnseandNoble.com , and a host of others simply took the bookstore model , attached a 56 K modem , and declared themselves The Future .
8,9 ORG|10,11 ORG|14,15 ORG|20,21 FAC
8,9 ORG|10,11 ORG|14,15 ORG|20,21 FAC

Netflix is doing much the same thing : Taking the traditional business online to cut costs and boost customer service .
0,1 ORG|18,19 PER
0,1 ORG|18,19 PER

III .



Who d'you think you 're kidding ?



You ca n't kill movie rental stores -- So there 's a big difference between movies and books : For books , the retail store is practically the sole medium of distribution ; if you do n't sell through them , books wo n't get sold .
6,7 ORG|24,25 FAC|29,30 FAC
6,7 ORG|24,25 FAC|29,30 FAC

For movies , the video rental store is just one way to get videos out there ( though at 45 - 55 % of studio revenues , it 's a much more important one than people think ) .
6,7 ORG|24,25 ORG
6,7 ORG|24,25 ORG

But given the high valuations ascribed to bricks - and - mortar - and - dead tree booksellers like Barnes and Noble , Borders , and to a much lesser extent Books - A - Million , surely there 's room for a Blockbuster , along with a Movie Gallery or two .
17,18 FAC|19,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|31,36 ORG|43,44 ORG|48,50 ORG
17,18 FAC|19,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|31,36 ORG|43,44 ORG|48,50 ORG

The latter , at least , still has room to grow .
1,2 ORG
1,2 ORG

By focusing on smaller , rural communities ( preferably the sort that considers DSL ' newfangled ' ) they 're WalMarting WalMart -- competing with Walmart 's awful in - store video rentals by offering better selection and much lower prices .
6,7 GPE|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|28,31 FAC
6,7 GPE|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|28,31 FAC

The movie business is changing dramatically as the potential for online distribution grows , but like every other business it leaves lots of room for traditional operators to operate at traditional ( read : high ) profits .
2,3 ORG
2,3 ORG

The aggressive bidding war for Hollywood Video , featuring two of their competitors , a buyout shop , and one of the savviest raiders around , is proof that some people still think these stores are worth something .
5,7 ORG|12,13 ORG|16,17 ORG|23,24 ORG|30,31 PER|34,35 ORG
5,7 ORG|12,13 ORG|16,17 ORG|23,24 ORG|30,31 PER|34,35 ORG

And I 'm one of them .



Full Disclosure : For once , I 'm actually writing about something I own : I have shares of Movie Gallery , I 've suggested it to friends , and I 'd be quite thrilled if the stock went up .
19,21 ORG|27,28 PER
19,21 ORG|27,28 PER

I do n't do ' sell targets ' , but I 'd probably hold the stock if it ran up anything less than 50 % from this level .



If I sell , I 'll post a notification one trading day beforehand .



Because Lord knows you care .
1,2 PER
1,2 PER

MARKETVIEW_20041212.1447



WEB TEXT



2004 - 12 - 12T14:47:00



WalMart : Conglomerating ?



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2004 - 12 - 12T14:47:00 Conglomerates are a fascinating species : The standard definition is ' a company involved in multiple unrelated businesses ' but the more accurate definition would be ' a company that relies on financial pyrotechnics , balance sheet juggling , and adroit accounting to create the illusion of growth ' .
5,6 ORG|9,10 ORG|17,18 ORG|33,34 ORG
5,6 ORG|9,10 ORG|17,18 ORG|33,34 ORG

I love to write about them , but I 'd hate to own one , since most of their market value comes from the market 's assumption that the company 's leaders will somehow find a way to retroactively justify their overvaluation .
29,30 ORG|31,32 PER|29,32 ORG-AFF.Employment
29,30 ORG|31,32 PER|29,32 ORG-AFF.Employment

Usually , it does n't work , but when it does the results can be spectacularly entertaining .



For a while ( see Ling - Temco - Vought or Tyco for details ) .
5,10 ORG|11,12 ORG
5,10 ORG|11,12 ORG

The recent rumors about WalMart 's plans to buy out a shipping company have given rise to the fear that the company may go the conglomerate route .
4,5 ORG|12,13 ORG|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|4,13 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary
4,5 ORG|12,13 ORG|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|4,13 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary

They have many of the symptoms of a late - stage conglomerate : A gigantic main business with slowing growth , fear that competition will substantially reduce the profitability of their main business , a shareholder base that includes many people who own only WalMart stock ( thus providing another incentive for intracompany diversification ) , and enough resources to pull it off on a grand scale .
11,12 ORG|35,36 PER|36,37 PER|40,41 PER|44,45 ORG
11,12 ORG|35,36 PER|36,37 PER|40,41 PER|44,45 ORG

I can understand the concerns , but I do n't see the motivation .



As a retailer of just about everything , WalMart can expand into some pretty broadly - defined areas without going beyond either their core competencies or some arenas where they can cut costs .
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG

After all , adding some international shipping assets to their holdings would be a natural extension of their enormously successful practice of buying the distribution network for their products .



They 're coming close to Smithfield Food 's very successful ' squeal to meal ' policy ; if these rumors are true , the result for shareholders will be a pretty positive one .
5,7 ORG|26,27 PER
5,7 ORG|26,27 PER

2004 - 12 - 15T21:28:00 Back in the day ( 2000 - 2003 or so ) some of the hottest non - homebuilding stocks were the gaming equipment manufacturers , who rode a wave of heavy reinvestment in casinos to produce huge profits . Now , all that reinvestment has paid off , and , along with a good dose of consolidation , made the industry moderately hot again .
28,29 ORG|38,39 ORG|65,66 ORG
28,29 ORG|38,39 ORG|65,66 ORG

Like every boom , whether merited or not , the big companies have big moves in the early stage , but it does n't get attention or turn into a mania until we see a frenetic IPO or two .
11,12 ORG
11,12 ORG

You know where this is going : Las Vegas Sands kicked off its first trading day with a 60 % gain after a last - minute increase in offering price to $ 29 a share , outside the $ 24-$26 range bandied about after they dropped their first $ 20-$22 estimate .
7,10 ORG
7,10 ORG

But , well , the business is complicated and the business is tough .



Wynn Resorts , another owner of the lucrative Macau license that captured investors 's attention during the IPO , illustrates this well enough : Steve Wynn , the company 's founder , made a gigantic fortune when he bet his company 's future on Atlantic City .
0,2 ORG|4,5 ORG|8,9 GPE|12,13 PER|24,26 PER|28,29 ORG|30,31 PER|40,41 ORG|44,46 GPE|28,31 ORG-AFF.Founder|40,45 GEN-AFF.Org-Location|40,46 GEN-AFF.Org-Location

When investors saw his $ 160 million all - debt investment turn into a $ 440 million asset in just a few years -- his net worth took a similar , though even less gravitationally - bound arc , rising from $ 2 million to $ 75 million durign the same time ) they all rushed in .
1,2 PER
1,2 PER

Needless to say , Wynn sold when everyone else bought , and he made it through the cannibalizing near - collapse those casinos faced in the early 90 's .
4,5 PER|22,23 ORG
4,5 PER|22,23 ORG

So , applause and cheers all around to the casinos raising such spectacular sums for your broad - scoped ambitions .
9,10 ORG
9,10 ORG

And a premature apology to the newly - minted shareholders , who will doubtless see some eye - popping returns in the right direction for a little while and then face a long road back to the reality that is a price around half the current one .
9,10 PER
9,10 PER

MARKETVIEW_20050127.0716

2005 - 01 - 27T07:16:00



China : We could always ignore them , right ?



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 01 - 27T07:16:00 One of the rules of thumb that has guided my ( limited ) business career from the beginning is that China is never as lucrative as it looks .
25,26 GPE
25,26 GPE

This assumption is based on about 150 years of economic history , including several booms in interest and investment in China .
20,21 GPE
20,21 GPE

Their biggest problem : There 's usually a 200-to-1 ratio of Nearly Starving Peasant Laborers to Absurdly Well - Off Government Employees .
14,15 PER|20,21 GPE|21,22 PER|20,22 ORG-AFF.Employment
14,15 PER|20,21 GPE|21,22 PER|20,22 ORG-AFF.Employment

And now it 's an iffier 100-to-1 , since there are also rich private sector employees and the labor force is n't quite so expendable .
15,16 PER|19,20 PER
15,16 PER|19,20 PER

What they 've been missing for years was the real driver behind any consumer economy : Consumers . Specifically , they did n't have a real middle class .
13,14 PER|16,17 PER|27,28 PER
13,14 PER|16,17 PER|27,28 PER

That 's changed in the last twenty years , as increasing social mobility and a burst in foreign demand has finally made China a genuine , rather than theoretical , contender .
22,23 GPE|30,31 GPE
22,23 GPE|30,31 GPE

And they 've even supplied proof of their economic viability , announcing that they 've beaten Japan for exports to the US .
16,17 GPE|21,22 GPE
16,17 GPE|21,22 GPE

If only I 'd figured this out in early 2002 , when their stock market was by some stretch of the imagination cheap .



Tanger
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

? ? ? ?



-??-??T10:10:00 I dunno if you want anything to do with their stock market .
12,13 ORG
12,13 ORG

For one , its perforance last year was pretty dismal .



More importantly , its a structural nuthouse .
6,7 ORG
6,7 ORG

Unfortunately , minority shareholder rights are virtually non - existent , and excluding the dodgy financial statements listed on the exchange , lots of times companies are more interested in generating cash from an IPO then actually bothering with shareholder value .
3,4 PER|25,26 ORG|39,40 PER|25,40 ORG-AFF.Investor-Shareholder

1,2 ORG
1,2 ORG

http://www.economist.com/displaystory.cfm?story_id=1447832



Finally , the Shanghai Composite on July , 1997 was trading at 1189.76 . As of January 27 , 2005 it 's sitting at 1225.89 .
3,5 ORG
3,5 ORG

That 's an annualized return of roughly .4 % .

2005 - 02 - 04T13:22:00



The Exponentials



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 04T13:22:00 It 's always difficult to get used to a central fact of the modern economy : The best new technology will keep getting better at an absolutely astounding rate .



Usually , the improvement curve flattens pretty fast -- the usual auto industry / computer industry comparison works just fine ( According to the standard urban legend , Bill Gates notes that " If we 'd been making cars instead of software , you 'd get 500 miles to the gallon , need an oil change every 250,000 miles , and be able to replace your car for $ 200 , " to which a mythical GM executive replies " Ah , but if Microsoft made cars , they 'd crash three times a day , too ! " ) .
11,12 VEH|12,13 ORG|15,16 ORG|28,30 PER|38,39 VEH|66,67 VEH|76,77 ORG|77,78 PER|84,85 ORG|86,87 VEH|11,13 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer|76,78 ORG-AFF.Employment|84,87 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer
11,12 VEH|12,13 ORG|15,16 ORG|28,30 PER|38,39 VEH|66,67 VEH|76,77 ORG|77,78 PER|84,85 ORG|86,87 VEH|11,13 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer|76,78 ORG-AFF.Employment|84,87 ART.User-Owner-Inventor-Manufacturer

Anyway , a few announcements during the last two days underscore the fact that the growth in memory and processing power for computers is far from over : Hewlett - Packard is developing a new replacement for the transistor , and a consortium of software companies is backing a new technology that would allow discs to hold up to a terabyte of information .
28,31 ORG|42,43 ORG|45,46 ORG
28,31 ORG|42,43 ORG|45,46 ORG

No idea where this will end up : It 's not altogether rare that these announcements result in a very expensive project to develop something that , for whatever reason , is n't worthwhile to consumers .
35,36 PER
35,36 PER

But it 's important to remember that the status quo is never more than a snapshot -- investing as though it 's permanent is a recipe for disaster .



MARKETVIEW_20050204.1337



WEB TEXT



2005 - 02 - 04T13:37:00



The " Twin Deficits " Myth



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 04T13:37:00 According to the usually reliable CNN / Money , the " Twin Deficits " will continue to grow .
10,11 ORG
10,11 ORG

Interesting terminology ... I believe they 're referring to the budget deficit and ... the capital surplus ?



When analyzing trade deficits , it 's important to realize that the amount by which imports exceed exports is also equal to the net amount foreign investors have bet on the US .
26,27 PER|31,32 GPE
26,27 PER|31,32 GPE

So the trade deficit is due to a confluence of the pressures from US consumers ( who control about 20 % of global GDP ) and everybody else ( excluding the non - consumption share of US GDP , that would amount to around 75 % of global GDP ) .
13,14 GPE|14,15 PER|36,37 GPE|13,15 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity
13,14 GPE|14,15 PER|36,37 GPE|13,15 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity

Which of those is -- probably -- going to be a more important number ?



Even if we are consumers bent on gorging ourselves with imported goods , the largest pressure on the deficit is that we 're simply a better place for investment -- higher returns on capital in developing countries are more than mitigated by the higher political risks they face .
4,5 GPE|26,27 GPE|36,37 GPE
4,5 GPE|26,27 GPE|36,37 GPE

And what about that other deficit ?



It , of course , is the ominous sum that we fund without taxes , but by borrowing funds .



And about half of those borrowings end up with the major banks in Asia .
11,12 ORG|13,14 GPE|11,14 GEN-AFF.Org-Location
11,12 ORG|13,14 GPE|11,14 GEN-AFF.Org-Location

So , not to be a heretic , but 1 ) We 're issuing them at relatively low interest rates , 2 ) Inflation is bound to pick up eventually , and so 3 ) Would n't you rather have our deficits made up by economically nonsensical purchases by non - US investors , rather than raising taxes in America ?
51,52 GPE|52,53 PER|59,60 GPE|51,53 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity
51,52 GPE|52,53 PER|59,60 GPE|51,53 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity

It 's a question of who will pay for the same spending , and all else being equal I 'd be happy for Asian central banks to pick up the tab .
23,24 GPE|25,26 ORG|23,26 GEN-AFF.Org-Location
23,24 GPE|25,26 ORG|23,26 GEN-AFF.Org-Location

The Twin Deficits are a reality , but they are n't exactly a terrifying one .

0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 06T19:51:00 At first , I was pretty skeptical of Gmail -- an announcement of something new , cool , and free , from a quirky company , on April Fool 's Day ?
29,30 ORG
29,30 ORG

Turns out my initial attitude was n't justified , of course , and Gmail has been a popular success .



Just this weekend , Google gave many users another fifty invitations , prompting some to speculate that it could be the start of Gmail 's final move out of beta .
4,5 ORG|7,8 PER
4,5 ORG|7,8 PER

Their marketing was absolutely brilliant : Simply through association with Google , and because of the invitation - only membership , they created a product with instant cachet -- something so in demand invitations went for $ 50 on eBay , and one enterprising site even offered a kidney for an invite .
10,11 ORG|39,40 ORG
10,11 ORG|39,40 ORG

And now ?



Everyone who wants a Gmail account has one , and yet people with invites have an almost pathological desire to give them away .
11,12 PER
11,12 PER

It 's been nearly a year , the service is nearly ubiquitous , and somehow Google has kept us obsessed with Gmail .
15,16 ORG

Poliblogs versus Stockblogs



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 08T20:59:00 Stephen of IRA - CAM is experiencing Sitemeter envy over all those succesful political blogs .
5,6 PER
5,6 PER

Understandable !

However , I 'd rather not worry -- instead , I 'd like to think of our situation as akin to Instapundit , or Andrew Sullivan , or Daily Kos in , say , the summer of 2001 .
24,26 PER
24,26 PER

Blogs did n't get huge until people saw them updated continuously on September 11th , and during the primaries , and later on during the conventions .
6,7 PER
6,7 PER

In politics , there 's a definite four - year cycle , and any new medium can find its voice and carve out an audience in that time .
24,25 PER
24,25 PER

Financial markets are n't so kind .



In short , we need a crash , and we need to blog it .

25,26 PER|36,37 PER|41,42 PER
25,26 PER|36,37 PER|41,42 PER

10,11 PER|19,20 PER

18,19 LOC
18,19 LOC

Northshore Management Update



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 16T21:20:00 Northshore Management , the hedge fund firm accused of stealing millions of dollars in client funds , is now facing actual SEC action . The amount in question : $ 37 million .
5,7 ORG|11,12 ORG|19,20 PER|26,27 ORG
5,7 ORG|11,12 ORG|19,20 PER|26,27 ORG

While it 's not a major sum compared to the amounts consider before ( as high as $ 90 million ) , it 's good to see that the issue 's getting resolved .



Though , of course , there 's always the chance that these fund managers were stupid and shortsighted , not actually criminal ; apparently , the money stolen was lent to or invested in companies the managers controlled -- so they 're guilty of front - running , at the least .
13,14 PER|34,35 ORG|36,37 PER|34,37 ORG-AFF.Investor-Shareholder
13,14 PER|34,35 ORG|36,37 PER|34,37 ORG-AFF.Investor-Shareholder

But they might have been using Northshore as an alternative source of capital : Having invested all they could risk , it would only make sense to turn to other sources .
6,7 ORG
6,7 ORG

What we 'll need to look for in the coming weeks are 1 ) What happened to the money once it was invested in these companies ( were they real companies , or just avenues for stolen funds ? ) and 2 ) How much of this was disclosed beforehand .
25,26 ORG|30,31 ORG|34,35 ORG
25,26 ORG|30,31 ORG|34,35 ORG

Byrne

2005 - 02 - 17T21:15:00 Has the EU once again lost its mind ?
7,8 GPE
7,8 GPE

The one industry in which Europe incontrovertibly beats the US is their aviation industry , thanks mainly to the fact that their lawmakers have left the operation of the industry up to the people who own it , and left passenger 's rights in the hands of choosy passengers .
5,6 GPE|9,10 GPE|22,23 PER|33,34 PER|40,42 PER|48,49 PER
5,6 GPE|9,10 GPE|22,23 PER|33,34 PER|40,42 PER|48,49 PER

24,25 ORG
24,25 ORG

MARKETVIEW_20050222.0729



WEB TEXT



2005 - 02 - 22T07:29:00



Russia : Pure potential , or , potentially , nothing



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 22T07:29:00 Read this report on the U.S .- Russia Technology Symposium .
10,11 GPE|12,13 GPE
10,11 GPE|12,13 GPE

It 's a great summary of the paradoxes of the Russian economy : They have a huge untapped supply of valuable IT labor , but their IT exports are only a tenth of their military exports ( and only a thirtieth of India 's IT exports ) .
10,11 GPE|42,43 GPE
10,11 GPE|42,43 GPE

They develop lots of new technology , but nobody can tell who owns what .



And , of course , their securities laws and property rights are even flimsier than China 's -- after the Putin administration mugged Yukos on the grounds that it was too attractive a target to leave alone , they lost a lot of trust .
15,16 GPE|20,21 PER|21,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|33,34 ORG
15,16 GPE|20,21 PER|21,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|33,34 ORG

Still , they have an unbelieveable amount of untapped potential .

MARKETVIEW_20050226.1307



WEB TEXT



2005 - 02 - 26T13:07:00



Choicepoint 's biggest screwup



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 26T13:07:00 We all know by now that Choicepoint allowed some highly respectable Nigerian businessmen of impeccable credentials to view hundreds of thousands of customer records for entirely legitimate purposes -- they were paying customers , after all , and The Customer is Always Right .
11,12 ORG|16,17 GPE|17,18 PER|27,28 PER|37,38 PER|44,45 PER|16,18 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity
11,12 ORG|16,17 GPE|17,18 PER|27,28 PER|37,38 PER|44,45 PER|16,18 GEN-AFF.Citizen-Resident-Religion-Ethnicity

But even after that huge mistake -- or rather , because of it -- the company 's top executives began dumping shares like mad .
15,16 ORG|18,19 PER|15,19 ORG-AFF.Employment
15,16 ORG|18,19 PER|15,19 ORG-AFF.Employment

What 's scary is that since they started selling , the stock 's down about 5 % .



Clearly , they were expecting lots more damage .



These insider sales were certainly stupid , and probably criminal ( though the legal proof may be hard to come by ) but the solution is easy enough : They need to buy stock from the company itself , at some premium to the prices at which they sold -- they 'll have the same stake as before , the shareholders would have gotten their money back ( since the premium goes to the company , which is owned by the shareholders ) , and there 's no need to disrupt their business by taking the matter to court .
36,37 ORG|60,61 PER|74,75 ORG|81,82 PER|98,99 ORG|36,61 ORG-AFF.Investor-Shareholder
36,37 ORG|60,61 PER|74,75 ORG|81,82 PER|98,99 ORG|36,61 ORG-AFF.Investor-Shareholder

Or , if you want to do things the SEC 's way , you could 1 ) Hire a bunch of lawyers with the company 's ( shareholders ' ) money , 2 ) Hire a legion of PR firms to explain away that frivolous spending , 3 ) Hire a new accountant to magically turn that spending into an investment amortizable over twenty years , and 4 ) Settle out - of - court by having the execs give the SEC some pittance ( for which they 'll likely be compensated by the company ) and a statement that " We neither admit nor deny that we did what you claim , but we 'll never do it again . " Thank God for the SEC -- they 've practically made it a shareholder 's utopia , here .
9,10 ORG|19,20 PER|21,22 PER|24,25 ORG|27,28 PER|36,37 ORG|39,40 ORG|52,53 PER|74,75 ORG|78,79 PER|81,82 ORG|94,95 ORG|123,124 PER|126,127 ORG|134,135 PER
9,10 ORG|19,20 PER|21,22 PER|24,25 ORG|27,28 PER|36,37 ORG|39,40 ORG|52,53 PER|74,75 ORG|78,79 PER|81,82 ORG|94,95 ORG|123,124 PER|126,127 ORG|134,135 PER

MARKETVIEW_20050226.1444



WEB TEXT



2005 - 02 - 26T14:44:00



Southern states considering higher cigarette taxes ?



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 26T14:44:00 Good plan ; cigarettes impose pretty high penalties on states , inasmuch as the states are caretakers for plenty of people who are ill thanks to cigarettes .
14,15 GPE|19,20 GPE|21,22 GPE|25,26 PER
14,15 GPE|19,20 GPE|21,22 GPE|25,26 PER

What 's notable in this debate , however , is that according to MSN Moneycentral , tobacco executives are attacking the tax by noting that " While North Carolina 's excise tax is only 5 cents , the total taxes given to North Carolina by smokers adds up to more than 61 cents per pack . " Okay , okay -- since the tobacco companies pay lots of money to the states , that 's technically accurate .
13,15 ORG|17,18 PER|27,29 GPE|42,44 GPE|45,46 PER|64,65 ORG|71,72 GPE
13,15 ORG|17,18 PER|27,29 GPE|42,44 GPE|45,46 PER|64,65 ORG|71,72 GPE

But the point of these taxes is to align the price of a pack with the cost to society , and inasmuch as these penalties are n't assessed on a per - pack basis , they do n't -- they 're a lump - sum reflection of the taxes these companies ought to have paid before .
18,19 PER|50,51 ORG
18,19 PER|50,51 ORG

Interestingly , the policy of making cigarette buyers pay to compensate society for the costs they impose is a politically palatable synthesis of the unpalatable notion of simply refusing treatment unless they pay full cost .
7,8 PER|11,12 PER
7,8 PER|11,12 PER

They 're basically buying future medical care throughout their lives , rather than eventually making the ( healthy ) remainder of the populace pay up .
19,20 PER|22,23 GPE
19,20 PER|22,23 GPE

In short : Good plan .

Icahn 's back !



Byrne
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

2005 - 02 - 28T22:11:00 You 'd think he was busy enough with Blockbuster and Hollywood , but Carl Icahn is once again going after Mylan labs .
13,14 ORG|15,16 ORG|18,20 PER|25,27 ORG
13,14 ORG|15,16 ORG|18,20 PER|25,27 ORG

I 'd love to call it a classic raid -- he 's making an offer for the company , nominating his own board , claiming management can accept one or the other or both , and hinting that if they paid him enough , he 'd probably go away .
17,18 ORG|22,23 PER|25,26 PER
17,18 ORG|22,23 PER|25,26 PER

But the whole point of raiding is to outsmart an opponent , and that means the strategy changes constantly .
10,11 PER
10,11 PER

In this case , the most interesting twist is that he 's shorting shares of Mylan 's acquisition target , King Pharmaceuticals ; he 's basically doubling down on the bet that they wo n't acquire .
15,16 ORG|18,19 ORG|20,22 ORG
15,16 ORG|18,19 ORG|20,22 ORG

Not only that , but if Mylan bought him out , they 'd have less money to fund a purchase of King Pharmaceuticals .
6,7 ORG|21,23 ORG
6,7 ORG|21,23 ORG

Either way , he 's showing a lot of confidence .



Given his record , it 's warranted .



OIADVANTAGE_20041224.1007



WEB TEXT



2004 - 12 - 24T10:07:00



Who will lead the revolution ?



Would you believe MBAs ?



John A
0,2 PER
0,2 PER

2004 - 12 - 24T10:07:00 For my holiday post , I offer a message of hope for the business world .



In 1994 , I was a graduate student in Boston .
7,8 PER|9,10 GPE
7,8 PER|9,10 GPE

I was asked to moderate a panel discussion on social entrepreneurship for a conference at Harvard Business School .
15,18 ORG
15,18 ORG

The conference was being held by a new group called Students for Responsible Business .
8,9 ORG|10,14 ORG
8,9 ORG|10,14 ORG

I expected to see a small gathering of idealistic , slightly naive MBA students .
6,7 PER|13,14 PER
6,7 PER|13,14 PER

What I found was a packed room of 200 intelligent , practical , driven idealists .
6,7 FAC|14,15 PER|6,15 PHYS.Located
6,7 FAC|14,15 PER|6,15 PHYS.Located

These students were determined to figure out how to use business as a driver for positive social change .
1,2 PER
1,2 PER

I left that room with my eyes open to the possibilities presented by these future business leaders .
3,4 FAC|15,16 ORG|16,17 PER
3,4 FAC|15,16 ORG|16,17 PER

Fast forward 10 years .



Students for Responsible Business is now called Net Impact .
0,4 ORG|7,9 ORG
0,4 ORG|7,9 ORG

In 2004 , I had the opportunity to attend their conference hosted by The University of Texas McCombs Business School . Net Impact had grown to include over 9,000 MBA students and alumni . Approximately 900 people attended the 2004 conference .
14,17 ORG|17,20 ORG|21,23 ORG|30,31 PER|32,33 PER|36,37 PER|14,18 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|15,18 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|16,18 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|14,19 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|15,19 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|16,19 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|14,20 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|15,20 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|16,20 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|21,31 ORG-AFF.Membership|22,31 ORG-AFF.Membership|21,33 ORG-AFF.Membership|22,33 ORG-AFF.Membership
14,17 ORG|17,20 ORG|21,23 ORG|30,31 PER|32,33 PER|36,37 PER|14,20 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|21,31 ORG-AFF.Membership|21,33 ORG-AFF.Membership

The buzz words flying around the conference included social entrepreneurship , sustainable profitability , working with passion .



I met student after student intent on harnessing the forces of business and capitalism to improve the world .
2,3 PER|4,5 PER|17,18 LOC
2,3 PER|4,5 PER|17,18 LOC

These students understand that business is a powerful lever of change in this world .
1,2 PER|13,14 LOC
1,2 PER|13,14 LOC

Recently business schools have received their share of criticism for turning out graduates who seem to have lost sight of their responsibility for ethical action .
2,3 ORG|12,13 PER
2,3 ORG|12,13 PER

I can tell you that I am seeing a powerful groundswell of change coming from within business schools .
17,18 ORG
17,18 ORG

It is not coming from the faculty , or the alumni , or the administration . All these groups continue to pay lipservice to topics of social responsibility while avoiding any real innovations in the student experiences .
6,7 PER|10,11 PER|14,15 ORG|18,19 PER|35,36 PER
6,7 PER|10,11 PER|14,15 ORG|18,19 PER|35,36 PER

The change is being demanded by the students .
7,8 PER
7,8 PER

A little secret of business schools is that MBA students have an immense amount of sway .
5,6 ORG|9,10 PER|5,10 ORG-AFF.Student-Alum
5,6 ORG|9,10 PER|5,10 ORG-AFF.Student-Alum

Few choose to use it , but if they want they can fundamentally change their school .
15,16 ORG
15,16 ORG

Right now students at business schools are asking for more discussion of these topics in classes , are initiating service projects , forming support group for social entrepreneurs , inviting speakers to campus to discuss sustainability , social investing , non - profit innovations , etc .
2,3 PER|5,6 ORG|24,25 PER|27,28 PER|30,31 PER|32,33 FAC|2,6 ORG-AFF.Student-Alum|30,33 PHYS.Located
2,3 PER|5,6 ORG|24,25 PER|27,28 PER|30,31 PER|32,33 FAC|2,6 ORG-AFF.Student-Alum|30,33 PHYS.Located

Net Impact is often at the center of these efforts .
0,2 ORG
0,2 ORG

These are not isolated events ... This is a revolution from within .



I have no doubt that in 10 years we will see the vast positive impact that these students are having in the world of business and society at large .
17,18 PER
17,18 PER

In 1776 Adam Smith spoke of enlightened self - interest in The Wealth of Nations .
2,4 PER
2,4 PER

I often feel that we have conveniently forgotten his emphasis on enlightened which he defined as being committed to being a good citizen and steward of society .
22,23 PER|24,25 PER|26,27 PER
22,23 PER|24,25 PER|26,27 PER

I am excited and hopeful that this new generation of business leaders will bring this emphasis front and center .
8,9 PER|11,12 PER
8,9 PER|11,12 PER

If you are an MBA student and want a good reference for comparing how MBA programs integrate issues of sustainability and social responsibility into the student experience a good place to start is the Beyond Grey Pinstripes report produced by The Aspen Institute .
5,6 PER|25,26 PER|41,43 ORG
5,6 PER|25,26 PER|41,43 ORG

Happy Holidays to everyone ! !



OIADVANTAGE_20050103.0944



WEB TEXT



2005 - 01 - 03T09:44:00



It 's Good to be the King !



John A
0,2 PER
0,2 PER

2005 - 01 - 03T09:44:00 Here 's an entertaining little morsel from Business Week Online ( no byline given ) :
12,14 ORG
12,14 ORG

But on the subject of succession , those two look like role models compared with insurance giant American International Group Inc. ( AIG ) , whose aging CEO has no plans to retire .
12,13 PER|16,17 ORG|17,21 ORG|22,23 ORG|27,28 PER
12,13 PER|16,17 ORG|17,21 ORG|22,23 ORG|27,28 PER

Maurice R. " Hank " Greenberg , who turns 80 in May , groomed two sons to be successors , but both have since left AIG.Greenberg Sr. then created an office of the chairman in 2002 , which includes co - COOs Martin J. Sullivan and Donald P. Kanak .
0,6 PER|15,16 PER|18,19 PER|25,26 ORG|25,27 PER|30,31 PER|33,34 PER|39,42 PER|42,45 PER|46,49 PER|0,16 PER-SOC.Family|1,16 PER-SOC.Family|2,16 PER-SOC.Family|3,16 PER-SOC.Family|4,16 PER-SOC.Family|5,16 PER-SOC.Family
0,6 PER|15,16 PER|18,19 PER|25,26 ORG|25,27 PER|30,31 PER|33,34 PER|39,42 PER|42,45 PER|46,49 PER|0,16 PER-SOC.Family

Both are considered possible successors , but the board wo n't know Greenberg 's preference until his departure , when it opens a sealed letter .
4,5 PER|8,9 PER|12,13 PER
4,5 PER|8,9 PER|12,13 PER

Perhaps this is a good time for a quick refresher ....



The CEO works for the board ... end lesson .
1,2 PER|5,6 PER|1,6 PER-SOC.Business
1,2 PER|5,6 PER|1,6 PER-SOC.Business

I guess it is not as straight forward when your CEO is also chairman and one of the largest shareholders .
10,11 PER|13,14 PER|19,20 PER
10,11 PER|13,14 PER|19,20 PER

It would be tempting to get on my high horse right now about the need to separate the positions of CEO and Chairman but to be honest with you I do n't really believe that .
20,21 PER|22,23 PER
20,21 PER|22,23 PER

I know CEO / chair duality is a popular cause for corporate governance .
2,3 PER|4,5 PER
2,3 PER|4,5 PER

However there is little empirical evidence to suggest that separating these roles affects firm performance in either a positive or negative way . Having a combined CEO / Chairman does reduce the ability of the board to act as a check on management and this does mean that you need to be more critical in your assessment of the trustworthiness of the top management team .
26,29 PER|35,36 PER|42,43 PER|64,65 PER
26,29 PER|35,36 PER|42,43 PER|64,65 PER

This downside of having a combined CEO / chair is offset by ( 1 ) a reduction of coordination and communication costs at the top of the organization and ( 2 ) an increase in the negotiating position of the CEO when dealing with suppliers , potential merger partners , etc .
6,9 PER|40,41 PER|44,45 ORG|48,49 ORG
6,9 PER|40,41 PER|44,45 ORG|48,49 ORG

# 2 could be particularly useful in a dynamic industry .



I do however look more carefully at the top management team of a company with a CEO / Chair before investing .
10,11 PER|13,14 ORG|16,19 PER|10,14 ORG-AFF.Employment|13,17 ORG-AFF.Employment|13,18 ORG-AFF.Employment|13,19 ORG-AFF.Employment
10,11 PER|13,14 ORG|16,19 PER|10,14 ORG-AFF.Employment|13,19 ORG-AFF.Employment

It is important that you can get a sense of the trustworthiness of the CEO .
14,15 PER
14,15 PER

Is there high turnover among senior managers ?
6,7 PER
6,7 PER

Is there a record of regulatory problems ?



If the CEO is new , I also look at the performance of the CEO 's previous company .
2,3 PER|14,15 PER|17,18 ORG|14,18 ORG-AFF.Employment
2,3 PER|14,15 PER|17,18 ORG|14,18 ORG-AFF.Employment

I am most concerned if the fortunes of the prior employer took a sudden turn for the worse after the CEO left .
10,11 ORG|20,21 PER|10,21 ORG-AFF.Employment
10,11 ORG|20,21 PER|10,21 ORG-AFF.Employment

How to find securities class action lawsuits



John A
0,2 PER
0,2 PER

2005 - 01 - 05T09:22:00 Yesterday 's bad day for Krispy Kreme included some speculation that the new securities lawsuit filed against the company would be granted class action status .
10,12 ORG|23,24 ORG
10,12 ORG|23,24 ORG

If you are interested in getting information about securities class actions for a company , you should check out the Stanford Law School 's Securities Class Action Clearinghouse .
13,14 ORG|20,23 ORG|24,28 ORG|20,25 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|21,25 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|22,25 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|20,26 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|21,26 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|22,26 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|20,27 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|21,27 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|22,27 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|20,28 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|21,28 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary|22,28 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary
13,14 ORG|20,23 ORG|24,28 ORG|20,28 PART-WHOLE.Subsidiary

This site has a very easy to use search function and it might be worth the time to run a quick check on companies of interest to you as possible investments .
23,24 ORG
23,24 ORG

Researchers affiliated with the clearinghouse just released an interesting report about securities class action trends during 2004 .
0,1 PER|4,5 ORG|0,5 ORG-AFF.Membership
0,1 PER|4,5 ORG|0,5 ORG-AFF.Membership

The results highlight trends in types of filings ( increase in product market related filings ) , affected sectors ( big increase in energy & amp ; technology sector ) , and overall number of filings ( fairly steady ) .
18,19 ORG|28,29 ORG
18,19 ORG|28,29 ORG

Get the full report here or the press release here .
7,8 ORG
7,8 ORG

OIADVANTAGE_20050108.1323



WEB TEXT



2005 - 01 - 08T13:23:00



Shareholders Benefit from Employer Reputation



John A
0,2 PER
0,2 PER

2005 - 01 - 08T13:23:00 It is just about time for Fortune magazine to release its 2005 list of 100 Best Companies to Work For .
11,13 ORG|21,22 ORG
11,13 ORG|21,22 ORG

So now is a good time to ask a simple question : Why should we care ?



Making this list is certainly a source of pride .



It can also be helpful if you are looking for a nice new job .



Should anyone else pay attention to this list ?



Well , thanks for asking because I just happen to have an answer for that question .



It turns out that investors can benefit by paying attention to this list as well .
4,5 PER
4,5 PER

In a study published in the Journal of Business Finance & amp ; Accounting ( 2003 , 30:771 - 798 ) , Greg Filbeck and Dianna Preece found that companies on the Fortune list of 100 Best Companies to Work For outperformed a matched sample of firms along multiple measures of return .
6,14 ORG|22,24 PER|25,27 PER|29,30 ORG|32,33 ORG|37,38 ORG|46,47 ORG
6,14 ORG|22,24 PER|25,27 PER|29,30 ORG|32,33 ORG|37,38 ORG|46,47 ORG

This study is particularly relevant for investors because the authors measured return after the list was announced .
6,7 PER|9,10 PER
6,7 PER|9,10 PER

To often these studies use as a starting point the moment before information becomes public .



The only way to benefit from such information is by holding the stock before the information becomes public .



This study indicates that the Best Companies to Work For information may still be useful even after the information becomes public .
6,7 ORG
6,7 ORG

It might also be useful to look at companies that have consistently made the list in the previous few years and make an educated guess about their inclusion on this year 's list .
8,9 ORG
8,9 ORG

Search the news archives and see if in the past year the company did anything that might have totally pissed off their employees .
12,13 ORG|22,23 PER
12,13 ORG|22,23 PER

Massive layoffs , bitter union battles , stopped offering free massages , etc .
4,5 ORG
4,5 ORG

You might also want to be wary if the CEO or a bunch of other top executives have been replaced .
9,10 PER|12,13 PER|16,17 PER
9,10 PER|12,13 PER|16,17 PER

That can often generate a period of uncertainty in a workforce .
10,11 PER
10,11 PER

6,7 ORG|7,8 ORG|15,16 ORG|16,17 ORG|18,19 ORG|20,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|25,26 ORG|27,28 ORG|29,30 ORG
6,7 ORG|7,8 ORG|15,16 ORG|16,17 ORG|18,19 ORG|20,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|25,26 ORG|27,28 ORG|29,30 ORG

High fuel costs , insane pension obligations , and a highly paid , specialized workforce .
14,15 PER

12,13 ORG

34,35 ORG

9,10 ORG
9,10 ORG

0,1 GPE|4,6 ORG|7,8 GPE|12,13 FAC|18,19 FAC|21,22 FAC|24,26 ORG|31,32 GPE|12,19 PART-WHOLE.Geographical|18,22 PART-WHOLE.Geographical

3,4 FAC|23,24 ORG

This is an industry looking for a sustainable strategy .
3,4 ORG
3,4 ORG

0,1 ORG|2,3 ORG|7,8 ORG
0,1 ORG|2,3 ORG|7,8 ORG

So I will thankfully accept the low fares , bemoan the loss of food on flights , and watch these companies parade in and out of bankruptcy .
20,21 ORG
20,21 ORG
